name.description: Name of application instance as seen in DC/OS.

cpus.description: Number of logical cores to allocate to each service instance.

mem.description: Memory in Mb to allocate to each service instance.

disk.description: Number of disks to allocate to each service instance.

instances.description: Number of instances of your service.

cmd.description: A shell command for your container to execute.

placement.description: Constraints control where apps run to allow optimizing for either fault tolerance (by spreading a task out on multiple nodes) or locality (by running all of an applications tasks on the same node).

constraints.description: Constraints have three parts: a field name, an operator, and an optional parameter. The field can be the hostname of the agent node or any attribute of the agent node. Example: [["rack_id", "LIKE", "rack-foo-.*"], ["rack_id", "MAX_PER", "2"]]

region.description: All application nodes will run in this region. When no region is specified the nodes are constrained to the local region.

networking.description: Configure the networking for your service.

service_endpoints.description: DC/OS can automatically generate a Service Address to connect to each of your load balanced endpoints.

service_endpoint_name.description: Name your endpoint to search for it by a meaningful name, rather than the port number.

protocol.description: Protocole can be UDP, TCP or both. i.e. : "udp", "tcp", "udp, tcp". Mostr services will use TCP

enable_load_balanced_service_address.description: Load balance the service internally (layer 4), and create a service address. For external (layer 7) load balancing, create an external load balancer and attach this service.

load_balance_port.description: This port will be used to load balance this service address internally

volumes.description: Create a stateful service by configuring a persistent volume. Persistent volumes enable instances to be restarted without data loss.

local_persistant_volume.description: A locally persistent volume based upon the physical disks installed in the agent which has the capabilities of a single disk.

container_path.description: The path where your application will read and write data. This must be a single-level path relative to the container.

external_persistant_volume.description: A REX-Ray backed volume that is mounted on the agent from the network attached storage

container_path.description: The path where the volume is mounted inside the container. For Mesos external volumes, this must be a single-level path relative to the container; it cannot contain a forward slash (/).

name.description: The name that your volume driver uses to look up your volume. When your task is staged on an agent, the volume driver queries the storage service for a volume with this name. If one does not exist, it is created implicitly. Otherwise, the existing volume is reused.

options.description: Which Docker volume driver to use for storage. The only Docker volume driver provided with DC/OS is rexray

host_volume.description: A host volume is a directory on the local agent mapped to one in a container.

host_path.description: Path on the host filesystem to the location of the data you mounted

container_path.description: Path, in the container, where you wish to have the data mounted

health_checks.description: Health checks may be specified per application to be run against the application's instances.

delay_seconds.description: Time to wait until starting health check (default: 2).

grace_periods.description: Health check failures are ignored within this number of seconds or until the instance becomes healthy for the first time.

intervals.description: Number of seconds to wait between health checks.

max_failures.description: Number of consecutive health check failures after which the unhealthy instance should be killed. HTTP & TCP health checks: If this value is 0, instances will not be killed if they fail the health check.

timeout.description: Number of seconds after which a health check is considered a failure regardless of the response.

protocol.description: Specifies the protocol of the requests: HTTP, HTTPS, TCP.

path.description: If "protocol": "HTTP" or its derivatives, this option specifies the path to the task health status endpoint. For example, "/path/to/health".

delay_seconds.description: Time to wait until starting health check (default: 2).

grace_periods.description: Health check failures are ignored within this number of seconds or until the instance becomes healthy for the first time.

intervals.description: Number of seconds to wait between health checks.

max_failures.description: Number of consecutive health check failures after which the unhealthy instance should be killed. HTTP & TCP health checks: If this value is 0, instances will not be killed if they fail the health check.

timeout.description: Number of seconds after which a health check is considered a failure regardless of the response.

an_environment_variable.description: List of environment variables if needed

fetch.description: If your service requires additional files and/or archives of files, enter their URIs to download and, if necessary, extract these resources.
